body:
Interestingly, it looks like the SQLContext constructors are deprecated but the class itself is not, so Eclipse did not flag the SQLContext references as deprecated. I'll go ahead and make all those substitutions.

Also, I believe I will need to also make some Python updates, since the python code also uses SQLContext and apparently there is also some Scala code that uses it.
thanks, Felix. Were do you keep the document?

Hi Berthold,

this is the document that I mentioned in the email thread on the Scala 
DSL/API Design. I am trying to summarize all of the approaches that 
exist for SystemML in Scala. The goal here should be to align them (also 
in respect to Python).
Here is the link again, please comment/suggest/edit the doc if you see 
something missing (everyone should be able to comment/edit): 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1ntdfmSBB83zdcWZl2iv4yMsrA3ZHDM-mzX5lMfFpfeo/edit

-Felix

Am 26.01.2017 00:00 schrieb bertholdreinwald:
> thanks, Felix. Were do you keep the document?
> 
> --
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub [1], or mute the
> thread [2].
> 
> 	*
> 
> Links:
> ------
> [1] 
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/357#issuecomment-275260281
> [2]
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AEnPYZxvfCepJJ1GLOq_4MWwCtn_IwT8ks5rV9QmgaJpZM4Lsz8u

A distribution build was tested two ways:
1) Normal development/test build where jar name has -SNAPSHOT.  Verified python artifact contained -SNAPSHOT jar.
2) Simulated release build, i.e., removed SNAPSHOT in pom version name.  Verified python artifact contained release jar (i.e., jar file without snapshot in name.
@dusenberrymw @niketanpansare

Here's link to RC1 artifact which had the issue found during validation testing:
https://dist.apache.org/repos/dist/dev/incubator/systemml/0.12.0-incubating-rc1/systemml-0.12.0-incubating-python.tgz

It looks like classloader.py might also need similar change:
Line 58:             if fnmatch.fnmatch(file, 'systemml-*-incubating-SNAPSHOT.jar'):
Thanks @gweidner :+1:

Thank you @dusenberrymw and @niketanpansare for reviewing!  I'm attaching screen captures of examples run from Python Notebook where I've uninstalled/re-installed the previous/updated artifact and restarted kernel.

![notebook_matrix](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12058879/22320071/c7cc40c2-e33d-11e6-8a14-91b658513474.png)

![notebook_logistic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12058879/22320074/cb67abfe-e33d-11e6-8259-84f61f67f0a9.png)

For reference in case I've mis-interpreted anything, here are examples of error messages observed before making both changes:

![notebook_directory_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12058879/22320170/a93014a8-e33e-11e6-8233-3437b09e96bf.png)

![notebook_loader_error](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12058879/22320173/aca7aede-e33e-11e6-9058-e916fa209d1c.png)
Hah. I noticed that too by analyzing the different artifacts on apache site and maven site. Sent out an email to dev list prior to reading that thread.

@ckadner  Please see my earlier response.
I tried --dryRun. --dryRun works fine because it can create a branch locally based on commit hash user specifies. But when you run without --dryRun it fails as branch created locally does not accept any changes.
Do you see any issue with current approach added in this PR?

I don't think we need to find alternative solution. I want to make sure Release Candidate we will be creating with this solution  is right and does not introduce any other issue.

Does --gitComitHash parameter suppose to provide commit hash, not branch name? 

I run script with --dryRun and without --dryRun using --gitComitHash="Branch Hash", and had issue.
you would run it with `--gitComitHash="branch-0.12"` in order to create a new release tag on branch `branch-0.12`

I understand that. That is another confusion we may introduce for user who may try this script.
I would prefer not to continue with additional experiments, if there is no issue with solution I would like to get going with build.

The problem I see with your changes is that you introduce additional complexity which is not needed to accomplish what can already be done.

The parameter you propose to introduce `--gitBranch` conflicts with the existing parameter `--gitCommitHash` which already has some conflicts with usage of the `--gitTag` parameter when running the `release-publish` goal.

Git uses commit hashes, branch names, tags as pointers to revisions. Most git commands accept any of them interchangeably.

You should get some feedback from @lresende as well. But if you go ahead with your changes then you need to add some additional parameter validation to eliminate conflicts (even more if-then-else code)
Thank you @nakul02
LGTM. Thank you @sandeep-n!
Thanks for comments.

Tested locally with:
```
# build distribution artifacts
mvn clean package -P distribution

cd target

# verify main jar works
java -cp ./lib/*:systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -s "print('hello world');"

# verify SystemML.jar works
java -cp ./lib/*:SystemML.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -s "print('hello world');"

# verify src works
tar -xvzf systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-src.tgz
cd systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-src
mvn clean package -P distribution
cd target/
java -cp ./lib/*:systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -s "print('hello world');"
java -cp ./lib/*:SystemML.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -s "print('hello world');"
cd ..
cd ..

# verify bin tgz works
tar -xvzf systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-bin.tgz
cd systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT-bin
echo "print('hello world');" > hello.dml
./runStandaloneSystemML.sh hello.dml
cd ..

# verify bin without libs tgz works
tar -xvzf systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT.tgz
cd systemml-0.13.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT
java -cp ../lib/*:SystemML.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -s "print('hello world');"

# verify spark batch mode
export SPARK_HOME=/Users/deroneriksson/spark-2.1.0-bin-hadoop2.7
$SPARK_HOME/bin/spark-submit SystemML.jar -s "print('hello world');" -exec hybrid_spark

# verify hadoop batch mode
hadoop jar SystemML.jar -s "print('hello world');"
```
cc @bertholdreinwald
BTW, all tests passed here: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/251/

http://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/
Thank you for reviewing @dusenberrymw!

Thank you Deron!
LGTM

(The FullReblockTest tracked under [SYSTEMML-1110].)
Thank you for reviewing @gweidner!

Here are the notes from the discussion with Berthold and Matthias:

Native BLAS provide benefits as exploit SIMD on newer CPUs. JVMs don't compile packed instructions.
JVMs make copy of data communicating to native BLAS.

1. Single Node (CP).

A. Microbenchmarks.

Measure purely the BLAS performance leaving out all DML overhead, i.e. 5 warmup runs to have JIT, 20 runs and remove outliers.
Bypass DML and use direct lib matrix invocation driver.

Experiments:

* Dense Data, i.e. sparsity > 0.4
a. matrix x vector: 1M x 1K x 1
b. matrix x small matrix: 1M x 1K x 20 
c. square matrices: 3K x 3K x 3K
d. short-wide matrix: 100 x 196K x 512 <-- compare this nbr to GPU performance.
e. XtX 1M x 1K 

* Sparse Data. MKL has 6 different representations; for a quick experiment choose 1 rep, e.g. CSR.
Purpose of experiment is to find out if/how much benefit native BLAS will provide for sparse data.
If feasible, try same micro benchmarks as for dense, otherwise try matrix x small matrix case.

B. End-to-End

* use perf suite to run 
a. 1 of following: LinregDS, PCA
b. One of following: linregCG, GLM, L2SVM, Mlogreg (binomial)
c. one of following: kmeans, mlogreg (multinomial)
d. 1 convnet.
on sparse and dense data and data characteristics currently used
on single node

2. Distributed
Purpose of this experiment is to find out the "right" integration strategy, i.e. "switch" in matrix lib, or new instructions.
set MKL #threads to 1.
run 1 compute intensive case where we should see biggest benefit, i.e. scale up squared matrix multiply. Want to enable PMAPMM as it stress most compute. A CPMM plan would not be good as is shuffle-bound.


Staging: initially AggBinary only; subsequently look at decomposition/solve/cholesky kernels.
1. CP - dense
2. Distributed - dense
3. Decomposition kernels, etc.
4. Sparse? (staging of sparse depends on experiments 1.A for sparse data)

thanks for the notes @niketanpansare ; some smaller additions:

* The micro-benchmarks map to end-to-end scenarios as follows: A.a -> B.b, A.b -> B.c, A.cd -> B.d, A.e -> B.a.
* The purpose of (2) is to see how the differences in (1) carry through to end-to-end performance and if there are side effects in distributed settings which require additional experiments (e.g., GC effects, etc)
* If CP is staged independently, the block-level integration needs to be moved to instruction level

Since we are anyways planning to perform the distributed experiments before merging this PR and this PR already has distributed dense integration, let's make a decision (after the experiments ofcourse) whether to even support distributed BLAS. If yes, then we merge this PR as is and if not, then as @mboehm7 mentioned "the block-level integration needs to be moved to instruction level". So the revised staging will be as follows:

1. Either CP instruction-level dense integration or CP+Distributed block level dense integration.
2. Decomposition kernels, TSMM, etc.
3. Sparse? (staging of sparse depends on experiments 1.A for sparse data)

I have created a experimental setup for microbenchmarks as per @mboehm7 suggestions. Here is how you can reproduce them:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml.git
git checkout switch_blas_experiment  
mvn package -P standalone-jar
cp target/systemml*standalone.jar SystemML.jar
for i in 1 2 ...
do
        java -Xmx40G -server -cp SystemML.jar:commons-io-2.4.jar org.apache.sysml.api.DMLScript -exp $i
done
```

Regarding the sparse experiments, I implemented initial prototype for sparse matrix multiply, but for some reason the output is all zeros:
https://github.com/niketanpansare/incubator-systemml/blob/switch_blas_experiment/src/main/cpp/libmatrixmult.cpp#L80 ... @bertholdreinwald @mboehm7 @nakul02 Since you have more experience with our sparse matrix multiplication, please let me know if you have suggestions to fix the bug. Once the bug is fixed, I can run the sparse experiments.

The end-to-end experiments are waiting for cluster availability.

Preview here: http://deroneriksson.github.io/incubator-systemml/

Maybe I could tone down the orange. I darkened the main text font color since it's nice to have a darker color when reading lots of documentation.
@fschueler What do you think about dimming the link orange from `#FF5003` to `#FF7032`? I'll update the preview.

I was looking at the MLContext section and because there are so many links it just made it a big orange wall. I actually like the current green/turquise/whatever color it is.

But I guess that's a matter of taste here ;)

I like both. I think toning down the orange is good since it blends in more now when pages have lots of links. It might be good to not use bold/strong font weights with the orange too (we have a lot on the Overview page) since the orange is already such a strong color.

@fschueler @gweidner 
Do you think this is ready to merge?

Thank you @deroneriksson !
LGTM

@niketanpansare I'm encouraged by the work in this thread so far, but unfortunately I need to bring up one item. I don't believe we will be able to include the `.so` and `.dll` shared library binaries into the source code, per Apache rules.  When we started, we had to remove existing `.dll` files since they are considered opaque "binary" files. It would be good to double check on this though.
@deroneriksson Does that imply that our src release should have the ability to target the GPU backend once it is built?

Based on @deroneriksson, we will have to cleanup [the resources](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/344/files#diff-600376dffeb79835ede4a0b285078036R120) before compiling the src distribution.

@dusenberrymw 
Apache release policy for source releases (http://www.apache.org/legal/release-policy.html#source-packages) says:
"Every ASF release MUST contain one or more source packages, which MUST be sufficient for a user to build and test the release provided they have access to the appropriate platform and tools."

At same time, these source artifacts can't contain binaries such as dll files, which we experienced with hadoop.dll and winutils.exe.

It seems to me that the main restriction is that the source releases can't contain binaries but the binary releases can contain binaries. I think that is the restriction and you can do most things as long as you work within the Apache guidelines.
It's good to verify this with our mentors @lresende @hsaputra

@niketanpansare src/assembly/source.xml contains an example of excluding hadoop_bin_windows from the source artifacts:
L53: `<exclude>./src/test/config/hadoop_bin_windows/**</exclude>`

That is correct. No binary files, including so or dll should be in source artifact release.

Need to be able to build in runtime or have config to use the native BLAS option

This addresses issue seen with:
```
spark-submit --driver-class-path $SYSTEMML_HOME/SystemML.jar test_mllearn_df.py
```
that gives:
```
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.apache.spark.ml.linalg.SparseVector cannot be cast to org.apache.spark.mllib.linalg.Vector
	at org.apache.sysml.runtime.instructions.spark.utils.RDDConverterUtils.countNnz(RDDConverterUtils.java:314)
```

All tests passed here: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/256/

cc @iyounus
RDDConverterUtilsExt is an internal SystemML class (not an API class) with 0 references in the project. It should not be called by external users.

Can validate with:
```
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val scr = dml("A=matrix('1 2 3 4', rows=2, cols=2);write(A, 'A.csv', format='csv');")
ml.execute(scr)
val scr2 = dml("A=read('A.csv', cols_in_block=X); print(toString(A));");
val X : Long = 5
scr2.in("X", X).out("A")
ml.execute(scr2).getMatrix("A").toDF().show()
```

cc @dusenberrymw

We also have to change our documentation accordingly. Currently the [LinarRegression Example](https://apache.github.io/incubator-systemml/spark-mlcontext-programming-guide#generate-linear-regression-test-data) uses the old version. Also: The `LinearDataGenerator` only generates "old" `mllib.regression.LabeledPoint` while the `LinearRegression.fit()` function doesn't take those as input.
@dusenberrymw Thanks for reviewing!
`RDDConverterUtilsExt` is documented and might make it seem like it should be a user-facing API. We might want to change the docs there too if we don't want people to use it.

@fschueler With the new MLContext API, all conversions can either happen automatically or via api.mlcontext.MLContextConversionUtil, thus under the API package. If RDDConverterUtils/RDDConverterUtilsExt methods are needed that are not included in MLContextConversionUtil, please add wrappers to these calls to MLContextConversionUtil so that we can avoid tightly coupling user code to our internal code.

@fschueler Additionally RDDConverterUtilsExt has this javadoc, which suggests that these conversion utils are not guaranteed to be thoroughly tested and that they will move. This is one more good reason to move any needed converters to MLContextConversionUtil and to use this class in our documentation.
```
/**
 * NOTE: These are experimental converter utils. Once thoroughly tested, they
 * can be moved to RDDConverterUtils.
 */
```
Okay, maybe we can remove `RDDConverterUtilsExt` from the docs then.
LGTM. Thank you @fschueler!

I'm going to go ahead and merge this optional troubleshooting feature since it does not affect the existing default behavior and needs to manually be turned on for debugging purposes. If it causes issues for users, I can remove it from master.
LGTM

@niketanpansare What about those methods?

I was addressing @iyounus comment about investigating the failing python test. My suspicion is that these methods are probably the cause of the failures as they invoke corresponding [MLLib methods](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/blob/master/src/main/python/systemml/mlcontext.py#L78).

All tests passed: https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-PullRequestBuilder/1069/console

@niketanpansare Does this PR look good to you? I deleted stringDataFrameToVectorDataFrame() since Vectors.parse() doesn't exist for Vectors in the ml package and this method is not used in the project. If this method is needed by someone, perhaps it can be migrated to Spark 2 in another PR?
I am ok to delete this method for now, but make sure to have Jira opened to get it added in new MLcontext API after 0.13 release.

Before this PR, many ClassCastExceptions occur. This PR allows @iyounus to investigate the deeper scoring issue.
@fschueler we can either go with this approach or cleanup the monitoring utils as in https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/376
I don't know enough about the monitoring utils to decide that, that's why I went with the minimal fix ;)
Makes sense. Do you mind closing this PR in favor of [cleanup](https://github.com/apache/incubator-systemml/pull/376)  ?

LGTM. I am fine with this since I am not aware of anyone using this functionality and removing it gives cleaner code. The monitoring util is saved in git history for those wishing to reference it or if it needs to be restored.

Always happy to remove stuff! 
You can link it to [SYSTEMML-1128](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-1228)

@dusenberrymw @bertholdreinwald 
I think a larger issue is whether "algorithm customizability" is one of the main benefits of SystemML that we are promoting. Algorithm wrappers and pulling scripts from the jar basically are saying we're taking a static rather than dynamic approach.
@dusenberrymw Perhaps a Python developer or data scientist can take on this issue in a separate JIRA issue and PR?
Thank you for reviewing @dusenberrymw!
LGTM. Thank you @fschueler. This keeps the Spark MLContext Programming Guide focused on the new API.

well, besides (1) custom analytics, there is also the argument of (2) adaptation to changing data and cluster characteristics. For me, referencing existing dml scripts is a must have feature (that should preferably be consistent across all APIs and language bindings).

Rather than simply disabling any binary block reblocks, it would be better to expose both brlen and bclen in our configuration file and respective APIs in order to avoid confusion. If the input blocksizes match the current configuration, there is no reblock; otherwise, we'll bring the input into the requested blocking scheme (i.e., we should stick to the current semantics).   

Making the change towards rectangular blocks would mostly entail (1) changing the configuration management and APIs as the compiler/runtime already handles rectangular blocksizes, and (2) testing this at scale with good coverage (e.g., with our perf testsuite) as I would expect a number of related issues showing up.

Thank you for initiating the switch including cleanup of monitoring util!

Can test in spark shell with code such as:
```
$ spark-shell --executor-memory 4G --driver-memory 4G --driver-class-path=target/SystemML.jar

import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext._
import org.apache.sysml.api.mlcontext.ScriptFactory._
val ml = new MLContext(sc)
val scr = dml("c = a + b;")
val a:Float = 1
val b:Float = 2
scr.in("a", a).in("b", b).out("c")
print(ml.execute(scr).getDouble("c"))
```

Since no one is giving this PR a LGTM, I am going to close this PR. If you would like this functionality, please contact me and I can re-open it.

@mboehm7 @bertholdreinwald @dusenberrymw
